description:
Each player or team begins with three pawns of the same color on the Ya But (start) space. In turn, each player/team rolls two six-sided dice, leave start, and advance around the outer track in either direction.  A player/team may roll a die and advance again when answering a question about religion correctly. There are two sets of question cards. One set for beginners; another set for advanced players. Each card contains six questions. The asker simply asks the next question on the card. The correct response is on the back of the card. There is no penalty for a wrong answer. However, if while taking one’s turn that player says, “Yeah, but” then the player’s pawn is sent back to the starting space.

Players must follow the instructions on any space on which one’s pawn rests. A player may not advance a second pawn until the first pawn has reached Home of Humility (finish). The third pawn may not be moved until the second pawn has reached the finish space.  A pawn does not have to reach the finish space by exact count. Any unused movement points are given to the next pawn. The first player/team to get all three of one's pawns to the finish is the winner.

You've been planning for years and have finally done it, you have made your way into the city vault where the precious Elestar Crystal is kept. However now you must race and battle opponents, slip past security guards, dodge bullets, avoid lasers, find the crystal and escape to safety with your prize, for in this safe, nobody is safe.

This is a print and play game with a 5-piece double-sided modular board, originally created for the 2017 Nine Card Nano-game Print and Play contest. The rules for setting up the game are quite loose allowing for many variations and levels of play. You can even make up your own special rules for the boards you make (for example you must touch all five cards of the board before leaving the vault). You can overlap boards, you can use less than 5 boards, you can use the sample boards in the rules, you can decide how many security guards to play with (if there are less players you could even use the unused player meeples as security guards for extra challenge), you can decide if you want to use the holographic crystal, etc. the point of it is, get creative. Once you have a board set up, you and the other players must race to grab the crystal while dodging around walls, avoiding lasers and security guards, and dueling each other to grab the crystal out of the hands of the opponent. Then you must get back to the vault door and punch in the code to escape into the night with your prize.

In addition to printing the files for this game you will also need:
-4 different colored meeples
-3 black meeples
-2 acrylic crystals
-3 green d6s
-3 red d6s
-1 black d6

—description from the designer

Your Inteligence Agency has received news of leaks of information to a foreign country. Your team has been commissioned to attend one of the most committed embassies. You must send your Agents to gather information, your Infiltrators to protect them and your Recruiters to try capture rival agents.

In La Agencia: Misión Embajada, every player takes  8 cards. 1 Agent of each value (from 1 to 5), 2 Recruiters and 1 Infiltrator and shuffles these cards forming a deck.

Every round, the initial player, will decide if it is played in the Gardens or the Hall. The players will choose a card from among their four (one revealed for all players, one unrevealed for all players, one revelealed only for the owner and one revealed for all players except its owner) to get as many Information Points. The Agents will provide you Information Points, the Recruiters will exchange themselves for Agents and the Infiltrators will exchange themselves for Recruiters (avoiding that can affect any Agent). At the end of the game, whoever gets the most Information Points will be the winner.

Your actions will make you gain or lose information, and you will have to manage your cards and your intuition well for being the most succesful player.

—description from the publisher

An n-in-a-row game using 'spicy dice' (6 sided dice that each have a different face colored red).  Players take turns rolling 1 or more or their unused dice and placing them onto the board.  When all 12 dice are down, the 10 scoring lines are evaluated (each containing 3 dice slots).  If a scoring row has 2 or more dice that are identical (even if they are owned by different players), then it will award 1 point to the person who has 2 or more dice of their color in that row.  Some other scoring patterns and displacement rules apply in special cases.

—user summary

Entanglement is inspired by the Entanglement browser game by Gopherwood Studios.

Entanglement:

Place tiles to create the longest path possible in the game of Entanglement!

Create an elaborate garden labyrinth by placing one tile at a time, connecting a meandering path of twists and turns. How far can your path go? You'll have to see for yourself!

You're creating a spacious garden surrounded by Sakura trees, but you have a limited number of tiles to play. Create a longer path and a larger garden by winding through Sakura trees: each pass acquires additional tiles for your expanding garden.

Should you risk your limited tiles to set up a valuable move, divert your opponents' paths away from the Sakura trees, or focus on an easy path through another Sakura tree? Weighing what to pursue when provides a mental challenge for those who hope to master it.

How is it different than the web game?

A few game rules deliberately changed to fit better for table play, but all the components are there if you really just want to experience a real-life version of the digital game. Here are the major changes:
The board game focuses on the limited-tile play of the Sakura-flavored Entanglement maps, not the boundary-based maps of classic Entanglement. This change makes initial setup much easier and prevents pre-placed tiles from shifting off-grid when they're not adjacent to other tiles.
Sakura tiles are dealt into players' hands instead of being pre-placed on the board. (This is for the same reason given in #1, and also adds a little more strategy and variety.)
Scoring is based on the total length of completed lines instead of on the length of individual moves. This change helps the game move a bit faster, since tallying scores like the web game isn't terribly fun to do manually.
The lines are thicker, and they don't glow. The thin lines were confusing to follow visually, and I didn't want the game to be radioactive.

Components: Box; 72 Hex Tiles; Rules Document; 6 (different colored) Pawns

In Wer war's?, known as Whoowasit? in English, players must find the magical ring that was stolen from the wise king by the evil wizard. Playing against a running clock, players move their playing pieces through the various rooms on the game board to uncover clues to who stole the precious gem. Along the way, talking animals help players solve the mystery of the stolen item with the help of a treasure chest that randomly supplies clues on behalf of the animals. Whenever players meet animals, they must feed them so the animals — that can be understood only by children — can provide the clues that advance gameplay. The clues supplied by the electronic treasure chest ensure that no two games are alike. All players must work together to find the stolen ring, and they win or lose as a group, depending on whether they can master an assigned task.

Wer war's? Limitierte Jubiläumsausgabe is a tenth anniversary edition of the 2008 Kinderspiel des Jahres winner that contains the original game described above as well as Wer war's: Das Kartenspiel.

Iocus Arcanus is a family fantasy board game, based on the amazing world of AitiA.

Every year, the magic apprentices must pass some tests that confirm their ability to continue with their arcane studies and become true mages. The great sages of Xrathgar, the Great Empire, thousands of years ago created three tests called The Trials of the Mages. The first trial is the Iocus Arcanus, a coliseum where the mages have no control over the magic and its luck that accompanies those destined to continue the path of the sages. The second trial, Draconis Arcanus, the search for the feather of the fenix dragon. And the last test, Arcanum Regem, the hardest and the one that really shows if the apprentices can lead the kingdom of Xrathgar.

The First Trial is held in this crazy coliseum, where the arcane energy transforms from one type to another. The apprentices will obtain different knowledge and the one who is able to learn them all, will win this trial. Of course, the other apprentices will not let you win, throwing away your soul from the coliseum, geting you out of the trial.

Simple rules, funny and full of magic, perfect for a family boardgame night!

—description from the designer

Explore the New World, settle unknown lands, establish trade routes, and deal in exotic resources to become the most prosperous colonial empire!

On their turns, players will be able to lay down their trade routes by placing a number of ships on the board. When a player's trade route reaches an island, they will explore that island resources and raise the demand of that resource on the Resource Market. Players can later settle the islands and trade the resources, thus gaining gold for the trade, but also lowering the demand of that resource, making it less valuable for the other players to trade.

Finally, the objective of the game is to have the most gold at the end of the game!

-description from publisher

Match compound words three different ways: word to image, image to image equation, and image equation to word.

There is always one -- and only one -- match between any two cards.

This addition matching game focuses on building Addition skills, teaching beginners the early fundamentals of math, while building and enhancing skills for more advanced students. There is always a match between any two cards. Find the pair between an equation and its sum, two equations or two sums.

This reading matching game focuses on the Dolch list of the most common sight words from children’s reading books, and helps prepare early readers for more complicated language skills to come. There is always a match between any two cards. Find the pair between a word and its image, two images or two words.

This reading matching game focuses on closed syllable and short vowel words and helps prepare early readers for more complicated language skills to come. There is always a match between any two cards. Find the pair between a word and its image, two images or two words.

Titan is a network construction game set in the distant future, in which you play as employees of Stardrill, an interstellar mining corporation. Stardrill has acquired the mining rights to Saturn’s largest moon – Titan - and is sending in a team to strip it of its resources.

Your task is to fill the hold of your ship with as many units of valuable resources from Titan as possible, in order to earn the most Credits by the end of the game.

To help its teams with their task, Stardrill has supplied a number of Extraction Plants - buildings which can be placed anywhere on the map. These extraction plants will allow you to obtain different types of resources. As you’re all employees of Stardrill, once placed these buildings can be accessed and used by any player!

Place pipes branching out from your main base to create the extraction network that will bring resources into the hold of your cargo ship. Each time you integrate an extraction plant into your network by joining a section of pipe to it, it activates, gaining you a unit of the resource of the building’s type.

Once obtained, these resources will have to be managed carefully, as you only have a limited amount of space in your hold! When full, no more resources can be added without spending or jettisoning others first. 
Some resources have value during the game and can be spent to free up space in your hold, while others can only score points at the end of the game - so you’ll need to keep an eye on the space you have, and time your activations carefully.

There are 6 resources available on Titan: Deuterium, Hydrocarbons, Silicium, Titanium, Water, and Tholin.

However, not all of these resources are desirable. Titan hosts large quantities of Tholin, an organic substance which could potentially cause you to lose Credits at the end of your mission. Picking some of it up is impossible to avoid as you dig deeper into the centre of Titan, but don’t let it get out of control – as well as losing you Credits, if you take Tholins into your hold when it is already full, some of your precious cargo will be contaminated!

Stardrill has also supplied you with a team of trusty drones that will lend you on claw on your mission. As well as transporting valuable resources and moving Tholins away from your network, Drones can dock to an Extraction Plant to increase its yield or make it less costly to upgrade. These handy machines can also use Titanium to destroy pipe sections, either in another players network, or even your own!

Earn Credits during the game by placing and upgrading Extraction plants, completing Stardrill’s special Objectives, and fulfilling Planetary Orders.

At the end of the game, you’ll score Credits depending on the contents of your hold! The more Deuterium you have, the better, as long as it hasn’t been contaminated…

The Employee with the most Credits at the end of the game becomes Stardrill Employee of the Month!

In this fast and colorful game of visual perception players slide rows or columns of balls in an effort to align together two or more balls of the same color. The balls that were aligned are collected and count towards the player’s score.

On their turn, each player selects a row or a column of balls (a line) and pushes the entire line of balls. The movement must stop when if continued a ball will fall off the board. In the process of pushing existing gaps between balls on the row or column are eliminated.

The result of a push must be that at least two balls of the same color must end up adjacent to each other (horizontally or vertically). The player then collects all balls of the same color that because of the move became adjacent to each other and places them in their tray.

Player who collects the most sets of 3 balls (same color) wins!

Can you identify the move that will allow you to collect the most balls? A fun and ingenious game for ages 7 and up.

-description from publisher

“Two Civil War Campaigns to take Richmond”

In the spring of 1861, Richmond, Virginia became the capital of the Confederacy.  Being a manufacturing powerhouse only 120 miles from Washington DC and the Confederate capital, it became the focus of Union attention. The threat of capture by Federal forces was constant.

The Late Unpleasantness covers the two major attempts to capture the Confederate Capital City. Gates of Richmond covers the Seven Days Battles with Robert E Lee facing down George McClellan. If It Takes All Summer is Ulysses S Grant’s overland campaign of 1864, which added the names of Wilderness, Spotsylvania Courthouse and Cold Harbor to Civil War history.

Each game stands alone, but share the majority of rules. Simple enough to learn and play in an evening, but enough twists and turns to make you want to replay it until it is worn.

The maps use a point to point movement system, rather than hexes to simulate the campaigning over the road networks and river crossings, rather than mass movements cross country. Combat is integrated into the movement, making coordination of large bodies of troops difficult.

The Gates of Richmond map covers the area from Richmond in the west to the White House on the Pamunkey, and from Mechanicsville south to Harrison’s Landing. Key features such as Malvern Hill, Beaver Dam Creek, and the bridges over White Oak swamp and the Chickahominy are highlighted. Will the Union army fail to attack the Richmond works as a result of “Prince John” Magruder’s antics?

If It Takes All Summer covers most of Central Virginia, from Brandy Station and Culpeper to the Cold Harbor north east of Richmond. The Wilderness features prominently in the campaign with a special table to create some of the confusion as a result of fighting in this tangle.

The basic units are divisions (a bit larger than usual for Civil War, but right in this case). Each unit is listed for strength and overall leadership/morale quality.  Stacks are hidden for limited intelligence. Corps and Army leaders are available to modify the die roll in an attack as well as to help coordinate attacks from more than a single stack.

Sequence of play is straight forward with supply first.  Units out of supply suffer movement and combat penalties and those with a continued lack of supply will suffer attrition.  Confederate supply is a simple trace to either Richmond or a railroad, while the Union needs to relocate his base to keep his offensive moving.

Units move, then attack as a part of the stack’s movement. Terrain, strength and leadership are all die roll modifiers, in combat. Combat losses are in terms of strength points, but a third die is rolled to determine if the combat ends in a retreat or continues. If it continues, you count it up and do it again. (and possibly again) If your leaders are good enough, they may be able to break off a losing battle.

Thrown into the mix are random events cards, but the game is not card driven. Each player can hold a hand of up to 10 cards, which can be played in nearly any combination and at any time (except during combat continuation). You use the cards to enhance your units or mess with the other player (ie. Grant steals a march - all Union units +2 MP this turn, or Rain - 1 left shift on all attacks) Others are one time events (Sedwick gets killed, Jackson falls asleep) that will ruin your perfect plan.

Each game can be picked up and learned in under 30 minutes, and played entirely through in 4 hours or less. The cards, leaders and Wilderness/Magruder tables add a level of chrome and history to the games without making them difficult. Combined with the hidden strengths and dummy counters, no two games are ever the same.

Complexity: 4 out of 10
Solitaire Suitability: 5 out of 10
Time Scale: 1 turn = 2 days (IITAS)
            1 turn = 1/2 day(GOR)
Map Scale: Point to point movement
Unit Scale:  Divisions
Players: 2 players
Playing Time: 2-4 hours

Components:
Two 22 X 34 inch maps- One for each game
Three Countersheets
Two decks of 55 playing cards (1 for each game)
Two Rulebooks (1 for each game) with examples of play
Player Aid cards with Charts and Tables
Three 6-sided dice
One Box and Lid set

Go Go Eskimo is a family game of Eskimos fishing and selling their fish on the market. There are no player pieces, but every player may play movement cards for each Eskimo. If the movement ends on or over a fish tile, that player collects it. After the market is reached, every player gets to sell one type of fish. The game is played over three rounds, and the player with the most money in the end wins.

Escape Now! is a cooperative game where players try to escape a randomly laid out escape room within 60 minutes. The 60 action cards represent minutes, meaning that players must complete the puzzles from the escape room before the 60th card is played. 
Unlike other cooperative games, players are not allowed to communicate with each other. If they wish to do so, that’ll cost the team 1 minute, or otherwise said, one action card. This means that there's no dominant player who influences the others and that players need to be resourceful and rely on the judgment of the team members.
If a team succeeds in escaping the room, the amount of remaining action cards state how many minutes were left to go. In that way, teams can challenge each other in having time records.

There are 4 possible actions:

     Solve a puzzle: place a corresponding trait card (i.e. 'perceptive', 'dexterous', 'talkative', 'tenacious' or 'logical') next to puzzle.
     Move to another puzzle: choose and discard a trait/action card from your hand and move to any visible puzzle.
     Replenish cards: Fill up your hand to 5 cards and then discard a card.
     Ask a question: Discard the top card from the draw pile and ask a closed-ended question.


With adapted rules for 2 players and solo mode!

—description from the designer

As an architect in Welcome To..., you want to build the best new town in the United States of the 1950s by adding resources to a pool, hiring employees, and more.

Welcome To... plays like a roll-and-write dice game in which you mark results on a score-sheet...but without dice. Instead you flip cards from three piles to make three different action sets with both a house number and a corresponding action from which everyone chooses one. You use the number to fill in a house on your street in numerical order. Then you take the action to increase the point value of estates you build or score points at the end for building parks and pools. Players also have the option of taking actions to alter or duplicate their house numbers. And everyone is racing to be the first to complete public goals. There's lots to do and many paths to becoming the best suburban architect in Welcome To...!

Welcome To... Mini is a smaller standalone version of Welcome To... that consists solely of six laminated sheets (10 cm x 10 cm), six mini-dry erase markers, and 55 cards; no rules are included in the box, and the publisher has stated that this version will be sold only as an add-on to the original Welcome To... game.

A promotional demo version of Kingdomino, released in the Stadt Land Spielt! Sonderdrucke 2018, a give-away bag for the "Stadt Land Spielt!" event on Sep. 8th and Sep. 9th 2018 in Germany and Austria. It consists of just 24 Dominoes tiles and is therefore only for two players. This version is made of one sheet (DIN A3, folded to DIN A4) of thin cardboard, supposed to be cut out with a pair of scissors. The rules are printed on part of the same sheet.

—user summary

Black Spot is a game of luck and deception in 3 wholly different modes

Treasure spot (5-10min)
Test your luck with your fellow shipmates to gain the largest amount of treasure as you take turns drawing from the treasure pile, but beware the Black Spots curse as its waiting to take your treasure away!

Liar's spot (10-30min)
Outwit your fellow shipmates as you strive to gain the most treasure. Draw treasure from the pile and declare your treasure. You aren't under any obligation to tell the truth about your haul, but your shipmates may call your bluff

Spot Roulette (Depends on number of players)
Someones going to get it, hope it isn't you. shipmates draw from the treasure pile until someone draws the black spot. Repeat this process until 1 shipmate remains

Battles for Prydain is a tactical level simulation that examines the fall of post Roman Britain by looking at 10 individual battles fought between 450 AD and 650 AD. Years of research reveals not just why these post-Roman kingdoms fought, but how they fought. Featuring warlords, javelin armed cavalry, Saxon shield walls, and special rules for Arthur (yes, the Arthur!), Battles for Prydain presents this period in history in a way never before attempted. In addition to extensive historical notes, the game uses a common rules set and counters to examine the following battles:

Aylesford (455)
Badon (ca. 516)
Camlaan (ca. 537) Two versions
Arthuret (573)
Deorham (577)
Argoed Llwyfain (577)
Alclud Ford (ca. 580)
Degsastan (603)
Maserfelth (641)
Strathcarron (642)

Scenarios are designed for two players, but a lack of hidden information makes the game highly suitable for solitaire play.

It’s Saxon versus Briton, Scot versus Northumbrian, and Penda of Mercia against everybody!

—description from the publisher

Weak Defeat Strong is a territory control party game for 4-8 players ages 13 and up. Runtime is approximately 30-45 minutes.

There are two factions: the Cyborgs led by Commander Felix and the Human Resistance Army led by a man only known as Johnson.

In Weak Defeat Strong deception is a powerful tool. With only the villainous Commander Felix revealed in the game, players must use their skills to survey the battlefield, discover who can be trusted and destroy those that cannot. Players must use their skills and hand of cards to battle and claim the most territories. The Faction with the most territories after 13 rounds wins!

—description from the designer

Based on the soccer anime and videogame.

Every player control one team of 5 characters with differents bases depending if they're defenders, midfilders or strikers. Each turn you can move, pass, use a super technique as double movement, double shoot or precise passing, then the defender can move.

The ball change when a pass or shoot is failed, a goal is scored or you have 4 turns attacking.

To shoot or pass you flick using your players, to move you just go to an adjacent position which has no players.

The first player to score 5 goals is the winner of the game or the player who scored more goals in 30 minutes.

—user summary

Mighty fights, max fun!

In Super Power 8, the players fight with each other in 5 fierce battles. Each battle, reveal as many score cards from the deck as the number of players. Every player simultaneously plays a fighter card from their hand face-down then reveals them.

If two or more players play the same fighter, they discard them. The remaining players resolve their fighter ability in ascending order (1-8), and then choose a score card in descending order (8-1). Those with fighters discarded draw one random score card. All played and discarded cards are placed face-up in front of the owner for the rest of the game.

After 5 battles, each player totals their points from 

     Values of score cards
     Fighter #3 (if successfully played)
     Bonus for having a certain combination of card colors (similar to poker hands)


The player with the highest points wins! In case of a tie, play another round and the player who plays the highest card (after resolving fighter abilities) is the winner.

Silhouette gratis Demo-Spiel is a free demo version of Silhouette Cards with a deck of 30 cards. It was released in the Stadt Land Spielt! Sonderdrucke 2018 for the gaming event in Germany and Austria on Sep. 8th and Sep. 9th 2018.

—user summary

Fields of Fortune is a press-your-luck card game of medieval city-building.

In the game, players attempt to build the most prosperous city while avoiding barbarian raids. The game consists of a 102-card fortune deck, with most cards being beneficial to a player's city, such as castles, city squares, military structures, religious structures, and treasuries. However, the deck also contains barbarian horde cards of varying strength that may result in a raid.

On a player's turn, they may choose to either hire mercenaries (if available) or add cards to the field. A player adds cards to the field by turning over cards from the fortune deck, one at a time and laying them out in the play area between all players (the field). The player may continue to add cards to the field until they choose to stop, barbarians raid the field, or eight cards are in the field. When a player chooses to stop, they then choose up to three cards from the field to add to their city. The cards are sorted in the player's city by type as the player is trying to maximize points by completing sets of the different types.

Each barbarian horde card has a strength value of 1-3. A barbarian raid occurs when a player is adding cards to the field and a total of 5 or more strength points worth of barbarian horde cards is revealed. When this happens, the field is swept (all cards are removed to the discard pile) and the player's turn immediately ends.

Alternately, instead of adding cards to the field, a player may choose to hire mercenaries if there are any available in the general supply. Mercenaries will help the player defend against barbarian raids by destroying barbarian horde cards in the field of equal or lesser value, just as a player's regular army cards do. A player who chooses to hire mercenaries may still collect cards from the field, if any, that were previously placed there by another player.

When the fortune deck runs out and no mercenaries cards are left in the supply, the player with the most points based on all cards in their city wins.

—description from the publisher

As aurora borealis fills the night sky with fantastical light, and the eyes of those who came before look upon you, it has fallen on you to lead your village to power and prosperity. Now is the time to grow in numbers and strength, to build, to hunt, to look to the spirits of the white wilderness, and to prove yourself the greatest leader of the Snow Folk.

Inuit: The Snow Folk is a card-based strategy game of drafting and tableau building for 2-4 players.

On your turn:
1. Draw cards from the common deck and place them face up on the table.
2. Choose one type of card to draft into your village.
3. The number of cards you draft is based on the number of Inuit of a given occupation:
   - Elders expand your village.
   - Shamans call upon powerful Spirits and perform mysterious Rites.
   - Warriors bring you the weapons of those they conquer.
   - Hunters provide precious game: seals, orcas, and polar bears.
   - Scouts allow you to choose from more cards each turn.

Inuit: The Snow Folk is a creative reimplementation of Natives, a 2017 release, updated with new lavish art and adding 2 new modular expansions: The Spirit of the Great White and Rising Sun.

In #SocialStar, players climb the social media ladder to become the first player to gain 40M followers! Players perform challenges ranging from acting, art, dance, list, and singing. If they succeed they gain likes and followers. If they don't like a challenge, they can always dump it for a dare. Complete the dare and the player gains followers; fail and lose followers! Do you have the talent, or do you just know how to play the game?

description from the publisher

The exciting Fantastic Gymnastics Vault Challenge game lets players imagine being the next star gymnast! Players time their speed and strength to launch the gymnast down the vault track. At just the right moment, press the red button to send her up and over the vault, and try to stick the perfect landing. Get her to land on the 100-point zone on the mat for the win! Step-by step instruction sheet also features tips for getting the perfect 100-point score.

—description from the publisher

In Strait of All Saints, a single player controls Magellan's fleet as it tries to find its way from the Atlantic to the Pacific, during the first circumnavigation of the globe. The player has to manage ships, crew and supplies, while discovering the then unknown strait as various events conspire to thwart the player at every turn. The player wins if the Pacific is discovered and reached by any one Ship.

Combining exploration (tile laying), resource management (food, crew, wood, weapons) and dice rolling, Strait of All Saints conveys the sense of adventure and anticipation felt by the original expedition. However, hardship was a large part of the passage as well, and the player is beset throughout by foul weather and unruly crews.

—description from the publisher

Yammy Yammy Coding is software educational game. Players collect material tiles to make chef cards, collect chef cards, to make the food card related to the chef cards. The player who makes the food card first win the game.

Yammy Yammy Coding helps the player to understand the construction of condition. Players can improve the computational thinking skill by thinking about the conditions and what materials they need during the play.

—description from the publisher

Robo-shop Chaos is software educational game that thinks strategically whether to make it faster than the other's robot or make it more perfect.

The games process of confirming the opponent's robot helps to develop sequential concepts and information gathering ability.

—description from the publisher

It's the matching game you love, now featuring Color Character Cards that add new levels of strategy and power! Claim one of the four color power cards to fortify yourself with abilities that strengthen your position! Comes with a full set of UNO cards, which includes 16 Wild Color Character Cards! These cards allow you to take hold of the powers – but make sure to use them when you can because anyone who plays a Wild Color Character can take that corresponding Color Power Card from another player! Game comes with 4 card holders to display your powers while you have them. You'll score points for each round in which you're the first to get rid of all the cards in your hand, and the first player or team to 500 wins. When you're down to one card, don't forget to yell "UNO!" Game contains 112 cards (including character cards and wild cards), card holders, and instructions. For 2 to 10 players, ages 7 and older. Easy to pick up, impossible to put down.

It's the classic matching card game, now with special characters that bring special powers!
Players take turns matching one of their cards with the color or number card shown on the top of the deck.
Special Color Power Cards offer special powers, but opponents with wild character cards might steal the power cards from you!
Score points by being the first to get rid of all the cards in your hand.
First player or team to 500 wins.
UNO is easy to pick up, impossible to put down!

—description from the publisher

It’s been a long week and you’re feeling rowdy. Roll up your sleeves – it’s time to start a rumpus!

Rumpus is a pocket-sized betting card game that is incredibly easy to learn and play. Aggress other players to show what a desirable gentleman you really are – but don’t pick a fight you can’t win! Oh, and please don’t start an actual fight. You are better than that.

In Rumpus, each player draws three cards, then chooses one card to place face-up in front of them so it is visible to the other players. Each card will consist of one of three symbols - Bicycle, Mustache, and Top Hat. At the beginning of each turn, the player with the Your Turn card must choose an opponent to fight. The players not involved in the fight may place a bet on who they think will win; be careful though, your bet cards will be lost if your fighter loses the fight.

The fighting players will select cards from their hand of a single symbol to play. Once both players are ready, they will reveal their selected cards to see who wins the fight. The player with the most of symbols of their suit wins the fight; in the case of a tie, there is a listing of which symbols are most effective against another symbol in the instructions (think Rock-Paper-Scissors). The winner will take a Victory Card and must read the description on the card out loud (e.q. "Good Show!"); the other players who bet on the winner will take their bet cards back and draw an additional card from the deck that can be used for future fights.

Once all of the Victory Cards have been drawn, the game is over, and the player with the most Victory Cards is the winner.

IntroductionBlockchain technology is changing the world, as people begin to invest into cryptocurrencies. Some smart and lucky people are making the right choices, and become millionaires. Many lose more than they can afford, falling victim to hackers and scams. Will you adopt the right strategy to win this challenge? Will you manage to build your capital in small steps? Discover that, playing with your friends, in an exciting but totally risk-free way!

Token Party is a cryptocurrency-based game for 2-6 players, who must achieve specific goals during gameplay in order to win. Players trade Tokens, invest and earn profits from mining, participate in airdrops and initial coin offerings, as in real life. They are at the mercy of the market index, fake news, security breaches, scams and much more. Game mechanics lead to a simple and fun gameplay, mixed with real-world rules.

				
				
					Game playToken Party is a turn based game. Players move their pawns through the game board, completing the tasks reported in the space they chance into, after rolling dice. Tasks could involve other players. When players land in the trading / hardware zone, they can decide to trade tokens / buy hardware. Game play involves collecting hardware / token / ICO cards, participating in initial coin offerings and airdrops, earning/losing bitcoins, paying maintenance to avoid losing hardware cards, and starting hacking challenges against other players.

				
				
					Goal of the gameThere are two play modes: standard and advanced. The “card-holder mat” must be turned right side up (light or dark). In both modes, the first player who completes all goals wins the game.

Standard mode (light-mat side up): Goals are broad, shared by all players, and don’t include bitcoin targets.

Advanced mode (dark-mat side up): Goals are different for each player, narrow, and always require to reach a target quantity of bitcoins. This requires a more cautious play. You need to strike a balance between completing your goals, and risking bitcoins in the process.

For more information see files and web links section.

—description from the designer

Get ready for the next sacred competition! As a predator, you have to prove that you are the best hunter of your clan by getting the most trophies, but you will still have to team up with your partners to finish your prey. And be careful not to underestimate them! The humans are trained for battle, especially one of them. Let the hunt begin!

In Predator: Partida de Caza, you are a group of predators who have arrived to the jungle to take part in a semi-cooperative sacred competition. Each turn, you have to roll the dice of your favorite weapons and try to kill as many humans as you can by placing the correct dice combination (number and color) on them. Be careful not to leave any human alive! If they survive your attacks, they strike back, taking away tokens from your threat board. If you run out of threat tokens, the auto-destruction device activates and you all lose!

You have to choose and play your dice smartly and also use your helping cards at the right moment in order to overpower humans. Let's hunt!

(The game includes various game modes, one is a scenario that recreates the first Predator movie, where you have to hunt down Dutch.)

—description from the publisher

Mathias Rex
Although Mátyás was elected as king in 1458, but Hungarian king may only be a person crowned with the Holy Crown. The crown is, however, was stolen by the Habsburgs in 1440 and kept in Vienna. Let's build together a strong, well-established Hungary to be able to buy back the Holy Crown and crown king Mátyás. A cooperative family game built on real historical facts, where we can only succeed if we are all together, helping each other towards the goal.

Players draw cards and follow their instructions to move the meeples, pay, occupy an area, etc.

A fast, fun, zombie-themed retro-style card game featuring a flying pig and a unicorn riding a tank! Be the first to build your horde and bask in the ultimate glory of awesome victory. Sounds easy, but your opponents will not just stand by and let you win. No, they want to block and quarantine your precious horde, so they must be defeated at all costs. It's a life and death struggle that only the greatest, coolest and super nice will survive.
     Gameplay mainly involves turn-based drawing and playing cards. Players start and grow their horde by placing cards of the same color in numerical sequence one through ten, but other players will attempt to hinder their progress by blocking, curing, and quarantining. There is even a Zomb-Fish card which allows you to steal a card from another player. The game usually intensifies as one player gets closer and closer to completing their horde, which usually ramps up the “take that” element of the game.

Setting & Theme: The cursus honorum was the sequential order of public offices held by aspiring politicians in the Roman Republic and the early Roman Empire. This game simulates those career paths, with senatorial factions represented by each player, during the rise of the Republic. Starting around 241-237 BC when the provinces of Sicilia and Sardinia et Corsica had been conquered through war with the Carthaginians, each turn abstracts a generation of Roman politicians competing for offices and wielding state powers, with factions leveraging their wealth and influence to increase their reputation and legacy. Senators also serve in provincial posts, protecting and developing the expanding Republic while amassing their own fame and fortune. Throughout the game players must cooperate to ensure the public’s satisfaction with the government remains stable and the Republic remains prosperous and secure, all while competing to attain the highest status.

General Course of Play: Each turn begins with die rolls triggering events in the provinces. Then elections are held where factions compete to form the strongest voting coalitions and senators claim offices in Rome and the provinces. Players then alternate taking actions that include using office powers and influencing clients, often with adverse effect on their opponents. Each turn concludes with a sequential reckoning of state and faction accounts, setting the stage for the next generation of struggle and achievement.

Disclaimer: This is a updated prototype that has been play tested, but is still in development.

In the year 2018, France finds itself, under the pretext of progressivism, on the verge of turning to  authoritarian rule.
A handful of parliament members opposed to the neo-liberal regime seek to counter the corrupt presidency by denouncing its abuses of power and blocking the passage of oppressive laws.
Meanwhile, the government has begun to create a private militia to obey its orders, thanks to the help of a shadowy figure: Alexandre Benalla.

Secret Benalla is a game of deception, lies and betrayal. The players are either opponents of Emmanuel the 1st who win by uncovering the corruption and unmasking Alexandre Benalla, Macronists who win by passing the oppressive laws of the authoritarian regime, or Opportunists who each have unique win conditions that are sometimes ... hard to decipher !

Be careful - even your allies may betray you.  Keen observation, scrutiny, and logical reasoning will lead players to triumph, but maybe not a triumph for democracy.

Secret Benalla is a re-implementation of Secret Hitler based on a 2018 French political scandal.

—description from the designer

In Microcosmos you represent a bacterial species, to thrive and win you need to grow and multiply, acquire unique characteristics of eukaryotic cells as the cell nucleus, improve your metabolism and evolve as many organelles as possible before the nutrients and environment's available resources are depleted.

The player that controls the bacterial species that has managed to accumulate the highest score according to their performance and number of evolutions achieved will be the winner.

—description from the publisher

This fast-paced, family-friendly card game has you tossing toppings and collecting pickles.

Flip a card and be quick to react to keep your pickle stash intact.  Take too long and you'll be passing pickles to your opponents.  The player with the most pickles at the end of the game wins!

—description from the publisher

Hank’s Hen Hatchery in known for the best fresh eggs in the county! But in the fall, the thing that Hank is known for is his haunted hayride. But this year…YOU ARE IN CHARGE of creating it! Of course, when you took the job, no one warned you about the upcoming monsoon season…

You will need to purchase and place various haunted hayride attractions on Hank’s property. Then you will draw the path for the tractor to pull guests around in the hopes of delightfully scaring them. Unfortunately, while you are planning your tractor route, the yearly monsoon hits, and you will need to contend with ever-growing flooded areas of the farm. Not only that, but you have to contend with Marcie’s Teenage Troublemakers on the night of the hayride, who love to egg the guests as they ride by.

Haunted Hayride is a roll-and-write where all you need is a few dice and pencil. In stage one, you are placing your attractions on the map. In stage two, you are drawing a path that you will take your guests on to visit those attractions while your property slowly floods.

—description from the designer

Various cards from Tark Mees Taskus,Tark Mees Taskus 2,Tark Laps Taskus ,Tark Naine Taskus and some unreleased cards.

There is letter in one side of the card and theme (mammals, cities, occupations, games etc.), image or mini word games in another side of the card. Turn around top card and be the first to solve the objective and you get the card as a point. If nobody can´t say anything or there is a tie the card is kept for the next round.
If the deck runs out the player with the most points is the winner.

February 4-9, 1943

Stalin had been unhappy with the progress of North Caucasus Front on Krasnodor and impatient to see more success, he ordered General Ivan Petrov, commander of the Black Sea Group of Forces, to break the stalemate by a surprise invasion from the Black Sea.  This would unhinge the German defense and quicken the offensive.

Almost immediately, things went wrong - with a bombardment from the Black Sea Fleet that merely alerted the defense - and the invasion itself was running far behind schedule.  So began the battle of Novorossiysk.

CSS: Novorossiysk is the first game in the Nemesis series covering company level battles on the Eastern Front.  With added special rules to cover the unique type of warfare on the Eastern Front, players will battle over the fate of the Kuban with tanks, amphibious invasions, paratroopers, naval ships and artillery.

Details:

Complexity: 7 (out of 10)
    Solitaire Suitability : 8 (out of 10)
    Time Scale: 2 hours per game turn
    Map Scale: 500 meters per hex
    Unit Scale: Company/platoon
    Players: 1-2
    Playing time: 2-35 hours
    Designer: Adam Starkweather
    Artist: Antonio Pinar

Scenarios:

6 scenarios included

Components:

2 22x34 maps
    6 countersheets
    1 rules booklet
    1 scenario booklet
    9 player aids
    2 D10 dice
    Box and lid

Wannabe Football is a fast-paced football card game with simple rules for the whole family.

It's a game of highlights that skips the ordinary back-and-forth play and jumps straight to scoring opportunities.

With five cards in your hand, you play, dribble, tackle, and shoot the ball to score them goals!

Wannabe Football contains 66 cards with no text or numbers on the cards.

Rules in 5 languages: English, Spanish, French, German, Danish

Immerse yourself in the colorful underwater world of Scubi the seahorse in Scubi Sea Saga: The Logic Game for All Ages.

Accompany Scubi through the magical coral reef and rescue his friends from the dangers of the deep sea. Collect valuable points before the Great White Shark goes hunting. What are you waiting for? On your marks, get set, dive!

The app guides the gameplay and provides help when you need it, along with new features and more tactical options.

•••

Tauche ein in die bunte Unterwasserwelt von Scubi dem Seepferdchen. Begleite Scubi durch das zauberhafte Korallenriff und rette so viele seinerFreunde vor den Gefahren des tiefen Meeres.Sammle wertvolle Punkte bevor der große weiße Hai auf Jagd geht. Worauf wartest du noch? Auf die Plätze, fertig, abtauchen!

Mehr Spielspaß: Auspacken und sofort losspielen! Die App unterstützt genau dann wenn Fragen auftauchen.

Mehr Dynamik: Zusätzliche Funktionen in der App sorgen für mehr taktische Möglichkeiten.

Mehr Action: Die App steuert den Spielablauf und sorgt für noch mehr Action beim Spielen.

Mehr Abwechslung: App-Updates sorgen für neue Features und zusätzliche Spielvarianten.

Thinkamabob the game that tickles every inch of your brain

What You're Playin' For: Use the Thinkamabobs + your big brain to complete challenges and earn points as you use the five areas of brain function: critical thinking, coordination, memory, word skill, and visual perception.  Use points to move pawns around the track and into your Winner's Row!

However, if you can't complete a challenge, be prepared to be judged, because as a group, all your competitors will decide your score! Just remember, what goes around comes around... (We really could have called this game "Think-karma-bob.")

—description from the publisher

It's Easy To Play!

     Flip over an Emergency! card
     Make a Super Me! match
     Be a Superhero


This game was developed to help kids recognize opportunities to help others.  Anyone can be a superhero by helping!

—description from the publisher

Kill the monster, grab the treasure, stab your buddy. That's what it's all about. Now, Munchkin has been transformed into a board game...

In Munchkin Quest, you can co-operate with the whole group, adventure with a partner, or strike out on your own. You don't know what's behind a door until you open it...then another tile is added to the dungeon. Battle monsters for power and treasure, or send them after your friends. Reach Level 10, then get out alive if you can!

Munchkin Quest: Big Box includes the original base game as well as Munchkin Quest 2: Looking for Trouble and Munchkin Quest: Portal Kombat.
